typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the fourth week of the course! 

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this week of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 2, Section 2.3) before proceeding on with this week of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

nodes.title: Increasing Internal Validity (Samantha Banfield)
nodes.description: TED-Ed. (2014, April 28). Not all scientific studies are created equal | David H. Schwartz [Video]. Youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUpd2HJHUt8&feature=emb_logo

nodes.title: Good Research and the Disadvantages of Peer Review (Cole Stevens)

typeData.textContent:
When a researcher performs an experiment, they are typically working towards publishing their results. Researchers may be inclined to publish their results for many reasons: they may want to allow room for others to expand on their research, be credited for their discoveries, attain sponsors or research grants, or purely for the advancement of scientific knowledge. It is important however, that the research conducted is of high quality because inadequate research may create misleading information that could hamper other scientists, organizations, and the general public. To counter this, the majority of scientific studies undergo peer review, where other experts in the subject matter provide feedback. Section 2.3 of the textbook talks about the many advantages of peer review, but the following paragraph will counter this by highlighting the many disadvantages to consider as well.

Peer review has many disadvantages associated with it that must be taken into consideration. The peer review process takes time, thereby causing a delay in the spread of information. It also consumes the time of the peer-reviewer, who may become delayed in their own research. Papers that undergo the peer review process can be subject to the peer reviewers biases, such as through homophily by gender which stems from researchers tending to favour the research of peers from the same gender (Helmer, Schottdorf, Neef, & Battaglia, 2017). Traditionally, peer reviews are conducted with a single blind, where the peer reviewers remain anonymous but the author’s identity is revealed, which can lead to the reviewers providing biased feedback against the author. Double blind peer reviews are also used, but often scientific communities are so small the reviewers can identify the author based on the subject or writing style (Kelt, n.d.). Peer reviewers are often considered “gate-keepers” because they help determine whether research is good enough to be published. This is important because poor performance by peer reviewers may lead to low-quality research being published or high quality research being rejected. 

Sources

Helmer, M., Schottdorf, M., Neef, A., & Battaglia, D. (2017). Author response: Gender bias in scholarly peer review. doi:10.7554/elife.21718.012

Kelt, M. (n.d.). Advantages and disadvantages of peer review. Retrieved June 18, 2020, from https://www.gcu.ac.uk/library/pilot/publication/peerreview/advantagesanddisadvantages/

nodes.title: Week 4: A Deep Dive into Research Methods Pt.1 (Imogen Seth)

typeData.textContent:
The course textbook (Spielman, 2017) discusses the placebo effect when talking about ways to control for differences between participants. In a standard randomly controlled trial (RCT), one group of participants receives experimental intervention, while the other receives an indistinguishable placebo control (Annoni, 2018, p. 476). This is most commonly used when testing effects of a medication, to ensure any differences measured are due to what is being tested, which preserves a trial’s internal validity (Speilman, 2017, p. 54).

However, there has long been debate over the ethics of placebos and placebo effects in clinical research, which the TED-Ed video only briefly mentions (Annoni 2018, p. 463). While many support placebo-controlled trials, it is still debated whether it is ethical to use placebos over active controls (Annoni 2018, p. 481).

In the last 50 years, the double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT has been widely renowned as the “gold-standard” of clinical research (Annoni 2018, p. 477). In contrast, Annoni (2018) discusses the RCT dilemma, which addresses the conflict between clinical research and clinical practice: the best way to test the effectiveness of a treatment may not be the best way to treat a participant’s condition (Annoni 2018). Deception is objectionable on the grounds that it limits participant autonomy and can breach researcher-participant trust, but when placebos are prescribed within appropriate ethical limits, Foddy (2009) argues that these grounds do not apply (p. 4). Perhaps one of the most well known examples of deception in research is the Tuskegee experiment, where the control group was left untreated despite the fact that penicillin was named an effective treatment for syphilis during the course of the experiment (Foddy, 2009, 8). Doctors should only provide placebos, argues Foddy (2019), when there is no better treatment or therapy that the patient is willing to take (p. 9).

Critics of placebo-controlled trials favour the use of active-controlled trials (ACTs) instead, where the control group receives an already proven effective treatment which is tested against an experimental treatment (Annoni 2018, 477).

Sources:
Annoni, M. (2018). Chapter Eighteen – The Ethics of Placebo Effects in Clinical Practice and Research. International Review of Neurobiology; 139, 463-484
Foddy, B. (2009) A Duty to Deceive: Placebos in Clinical Practice, The American Journal of Bioethics, 9:12, 4-12, DOI: 10.1080/15265160903318350
Spielman, R. M. (2017). Psychology. Houston, Texas 77005: OpenStax.
